title: The Birth of Isaac
shortSummary: Genesis 21 recounts the miraculous birth of Isaac to Abraham and Sarah in their old age, fulfilling God's promise. The chapter also addresses the tension between Sarah and Hagar, the sending away of Hagar and Ishmael, and concludes with a covenant between Abraham and Abimelech, highlighting God's faithfulness and providence.
timeline: c. 2100 BC - Patriarchal Period, during Abraham's lifetime

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch of Israel who receives God's promise of a son and faithfully obeys God's commands throughout the chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Sarah
keyCharacters.description: Abraham's wife who miraculously conceives Isaac in her old age, expressing joy and laughter at God's fulfillment of His promise.

keyCharacters.name: Isaac
keyCharacters.description: The promised son of Abraham and Sarah, born as the child of promise through whom God's covenant will continue.

keyCharacters.name: Hagar
keyCharacters.description: Sarah's Egyptian maidservant and mother of Ishmael, who is sent away with her son after conflict arises.

keyCharacters.name: Abimelech
keyCharacters.description: The Philistine king who makes a covenant with Abraham, recognizing God's blessing upon him.

definitions.definition: The physical sign of God's covenant with Abraham, performed on Isaac at eight days old as a mark of obedience and covenant identity.
The process of a child transitioning from mother's milk to solid food, marking a significant stage of growth and independence.
A female servant or slave; in this chapter, Hagar is referred to as a bondwoman, highlighting her social status relative to Sarah.
A solemn agreement between two parties; here it refers to the binding agreement between Abraham and Abimelech, sealed by sacrifices and witnesses.
A significant location meaning 'Well of the Oath,' where Abraham and Abimelech made their covenant.

outline.heading: The Birth and Naming of Isaac
outline.description: God fulfills His promise by enabling Sarah to conceive and bear Isaac in her old age, demonstrating His faithfulness and power over nature.

outline.heading: Celebration and Conflict
outline.description: Isaac is weaned and Abraham holds a feast, but tension arises when Sarah sees Ishmael mocking, leading to her demand to send Hagar and Ishmael away.

outline.heading: Godâ€™s Promise to Hagar and Ishmael
outline.description: Though Abraham is distressed, God reassures him and promises to make Ishmael a great nation; Hagar and Ishmael are cared for by God in the wilderness.

outline.heading: Covenant with Abimelech
outline.description: Abimelech acknowledges God's blessing on Abraham, leading to a covenant over a disputed well, symbolizing peace and mutual respect.

application: Trust in God's promises even when circumstances seem impossible, as God is faithful to fulfill His word in His timing.
Respond to conflict with obedience to God's guidance, trusting His sovereignty over difficult situations.
Remember to celebrate milestones of spiritual and physical growth as evidence of God's blessing and provision.
Seek peace and reconciliation in relationships, following Abraham's example of making covenants and resolving disputes honorably.

keyVerses.text: For Sarah conceived, and bare Abraham a son in his old age, at the set time of which God had spoken to him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's faithfulness and sovereign timing in fulfilling His promises.

keyVerses.text: And God said unto Abraham, Let it not be grievous in thy sight because of the lad, and because of thy bondwoman; in all that Sarah hath said unto thee, hearken unto her voice; for in Isaac shall thy seed be called.
keyVerses.significance: God instructs Abraham to honor Sarah's wishes, emphasizing the covenant line through Isaac while also showing care for Ishmael.

keyVerses.text: And God heard the voice of the lad; and the angel of God called to Hagar out of heaven, and said unto her, What aileth thee, Hagar? fear not; for God hath heard the voice of the lad where he is.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's compassion and attentive care for those in distress, including Hagar and Ishmael.

keyVerses.text: And Abraham planted a grove in Beersheba, and called there on the name of the LORD, the everlasting God.
keyVerses.significance: Abraham's act of worship and naming God as everlasting underscores the eternal nature of God's covenant.
